revised_title: Surface Lipid Composition of Brassica oleracea Leaves
tldr: The authors identified and analyzed the composition of surface lipids from the leaves of Brassica oleracea, specifically focusing on esters, free primary alcohols, and free acids. They used reversed-phase partition film chromatography to isolate and identify the individual components. The results showed that the lipids consisted of even-numbered carbon chains, ranging from dodecanoic to tetracosanoic acid for the acids and from dodecanol to octacosanol for the alcohols. The main component of the ester-alcohols was hexacosanol, and the ester-acids contained dodecanoic, tetradecanoic, octadecanoic, docosanoic, and tetracosanoic acids.
